content: The text chunk "MODIFICATIONS OF CREDIT FOR PRODUCTION FROM ADVANCED NUCLEAR POWER FACILITIES" is a section discussing changes to the credit for production from advanced nuclear power facilities. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the treatment of unutilized limitation amounts for national megawatt capacity. The Secretary is required to allocate any unutilized limitation to facilities placed in service before December 31, 2020. The Secretary must allocate unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities placed in service before December 31, 2020, prioritizing those that did not receive full nameplate capacity allocation. Facilities placed in service after this date will be allocated in the order of their service. The Secretary allocates unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities based on priority and order of service. The term 'unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation' refers to the excess of 6,000 megawatts over the aggregate amount allocated before January 1, 2021. The Secretary allocates unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities based on priority and order of service. This allocation is subject to a megawatt capacity limitation set before January 1, 2021, with any excess being reallocated to facilities not in service by that date. This allocation is subject to a limitation allocated by the Secretary, treated similarly to a national megawatt capacity limitation allocation. Subsection (d)(1)(B) does not apply to facilities receiving this allocation. Section 45J of the Code is amended to allow transfer of credit by certain public entities. The Code allows transfer of credit by certain public entities under Section 45J. The Code allows transfer of credit by qualified public entities under Section 45J. If a qualified public entity elects to transfer the credit to an eligible project partner, the partner will be treated as the taxpayer for that credit. Definitions for this subsection are provided. The Code permits qualified public entities to transfer credits under Section 45J. If the entity chooses to transfer the credit to a project partner, the partner will be considered the taxpayer for that credit. Definitions for this subsection are included, specifying what qualifies as a qualified public entity. The term 'eligible project partner' refers to individuals involved in the design or construction of a project, including mutual or cooperative electric companies and not-for-profit electric utilities that have received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. The term 'eligible project partner' includes individuals involved in the design or construction of an advanced nuclear power facility or providing the nuclear steam supply system for it. The term 'eligible project partner' includes individuals involved in the provision of the nuclear steam supply system or nuclear fuel to the advanced nuclear power facility, as well as those with an ownership interest in the facility. The credit under subsection (a) applies to the nuclear power facility and individuals with ownership interests in the facility. Any benefit derived by an eligible project partner in connection with an election under this subsection shall not be subject to private use rules. For section 141(b)(1), benefits from an election under this subsection are not considered private business use. Mutual or cooperative electric companies have a special rule for proceeds of transfers. Cooperative electric companies are affected by an amendment to Section 501(c)(12) of the Code, stating that income related to an election under section 45J(e)(1) will be treated as funds collected from members for covering losses and expenses.
